Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights

Legal_Issue: Whether the defendants infringed the plaintiff's trademark rights under s. 19, 20, or 22 of the Trademarks Act or committed passing-off
Procedural_Stage: Adjudication on merits with partial resolution; counterclaim dismissed, remaining issues deferred
Evidence_Assessment: Visual similarity between Explore Canada logo and Hilfiger's TMA '095 assessed; some confusion found; no evidence of goodwill depreciation or passing-off

Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to prove trademark validity, likelihood of confusion, and goodwill protection
Credibility_Factor: Court found sufficient credibility in visual comparison evidence to establish confusion for s. 20, but insufficient evidence on goodwill depreciation
Legal_Rule: s. 19: Exclusive right to use registered trademark
s. 20: Prohibition of unauthorized use causing confusion
s. 22: Prohibition of depreciation of goodwill
Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized use of similar logo leading to consumer confusion
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial success for plaintiff: s. 20 infringement upheld; other claims dismissed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Visual design of Explore Canada logo, comparison with TMA '095, product types, market presence, absence of goodwill impact evidence
Legal_Framework: Canadian federal trademark law under the Trademarks Act
Defendant_Response: Denial of infringement and passing-off; challenge to confusion and goodwill claims
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, visual comparison, trademark registration records
Remedy_Requested: Legal action for trademark infringement and passing-off, including damages and injunction
Outcome: Liability for s. 20 infringement established against Quality Goods; counterclaim dismissed; other issues deferred

Crimes.Crime_Name: Permitting another person to use a passport

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Hsu was absent from Canada for 976 days and present for only 119 days during the four-year period preceding his application; he lived and worked in Taiwan, visiting Canada occasionally.
Residency_Compliance: Did not accumulate at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal heard de novo before Federal Court Trial Division due to timing under pre-1998 rules
Evidence_Used: Record of absences and presences in Canada, employment and residence in Taiwan, family ties in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing centralized mode of living in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Hsuâ€™s claim of residency was undermined by prolonged absence and primary residence in Taiwan
Outcome: Hsu remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review allowing citizenship application to proceed
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada within four years before application
Decision_Rationale: Hsu failed to establish a centralized mode of living in Canada despite having family there; his actual residence and employment were in Taiwan

Crimes.Legal_Provision: No specific federal civil cause of action identified

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Jurisdiction denied, claim dismissed, costs awarded to defendants
